Award.AwardTitle: PECASE: Microstructure and Processing of Cylindrical Nanomaterial Dispersions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to acquire in depth, scientific understanding of the relationships between microstructure, processing and properties for macroscale materials produced from model cylindrical nanomaterial dispersions. Cylindrical nanomaterials are a particularly exciting new class of materials because they can be produced from many chemical elements; this enables a wide range of potential properties and applications. It has never before been possible to investigate systems with such large rod lengths, wide range of length to diameter ratios, high rigidity, and potential for large long-range interactions. The potential liquid crystalline phase behavior of the cylindrical nanomaterial dispersions will be investigated as a function of temperature, nanomaterial dimensions, and solvent interactions. Changes in dispersion morphology and alignment in response to shear will also be explored. This information will be used to optimize the bottom-up assembly of solid macroscopic films and fibers comprised of cylindrical nanomaterial building blocks. The research plan includes collaboration with Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique in Bourdeaux France.


If successful, the results of this research will provide a basis for controlling the alignment and distribution of cylindrical nanomaterials during the production of advanced macroscopic materials. Potential applications include macroelectronic devices, sensors, electro-optical devices, and antimicrobial coatings. The interdisciplinary education of undergraduate and graduate researchers is an integral part of achieving the research goals. As part of this CAREER plan, the PI will develop fun and rewarding experiences that encourage students to choose and persist in science and engineering majors. These activities include mentoring undergraduate researchers and facilitating the educational and career development of students from underrepresented groups. In addition, nanotechnology outreach activities will be incorporated into science camps for middle school students.
This project is jointly funded by the Materials Processing & Manufacturing Program, of the Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation Division and by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this PECASE award was to acquire in depth, scientific understanding of the relationships between microstructure, processing and properties for macroscale materials produced from nanocylinders.  Associated education objectives were to 1) incorporate nanotechnology into outreach, undergraduate and graduate education and 2) increase the number and diversity of people pursuing science and engineering degrees. Nanocylinders are basically tiny cylinders whose diameters are less than 100 nm in diameter and whose length can be anywhere from nanometers to millimeters.  The term nanocylinders includes synthetic materials such as carbon nanotubes and silver nanowires that scientists have only known how to synthesize in reasonable quantities. They also include naturally occurring biological materials such as DNA and the tiny high strength cellulose nanocrystals found in every plant and tree.  In the 20th century, the discovery of synthetic and natural polymers was followed by significant research on how they could be processed; this eventually led to polymers’ innumerable medical, safety, automotive, and consumer product applications. In the 21st century, the same thing is happening with nanocylinders.  The research accomplishments of this PECASE award provide a foundation for real-world applications for fields such as medicine, and electronics. In fact, one of the key accomplishments of this award was connecting the liquid crystalline science that enabled high strength polymer fibers like Kevlar with nanocylinder liquid crystalline  phase behavior and processing.   During this award, the ability to make all three major classes of liquid crystals from a range of nanocylinders with different chemistries and sizes was demonstrated.  The relationships between this  liquid crystalline phase behavior, processing conditions, and the mechanical, optical, antimicrobial, and electrical properties of the resulting films and fibers were established.

The specific accomplishments of this research have been communicated through conferences and publications. However, the research team has also placed considerable emphasis on increasing nanotechnology awareness and literacy of science and engineering students, K-12 students, K-12 teachers, and the local community.  Nanotechnology has always existed. Many pieces of ancient pottery and medieval stained glass windows owe their appearance to natural or synthesized nanomaterials. However, it is only in the last few decades that the tools for understanding nanotechnology have existed.  This has enabled many new applications including cancer-fighting drugs, scratch resistant paint, stain and water resistant apparel, and smaller electronics.  Nanotechnology also promises to help solve many of the world’s greatest challenges including access to clean water and more energy efficient solar energy. Therefore, nanotechnology education is important not only for future scientists and engineers but for everyone.  The PI and her team have also devoted significant time and resources to engaging students through outreach and to increasing diversity. This has included engineering camps for female high school students, and the establishment of a Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers Chapter at Auburn University.

Modified by: Virginia A Davis
